author: By Olga Rudenko
title: The Comedian-Turned-President Is Seriously in Over His Head
description: Volodymyr Zelensky has been badly miscast.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — It’s not hard to guess what President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine must be craving right now: one normal day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: With Sensors on Streets, France Takes Aim at ‘Noise From Hell’
description: The French authorities are installing “sound radars” in some cities to detect and photograph vehicles making excessive noise, which they say is a public health hazard.
content: When France introduced speed cameras 20 years ago, it drastically reduced the number of car accidents and helped save tens of thousands of lives. Now the government is taking aim at another scourge: the earsplitting noise that has been a fact of life for residents of French cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4 Million Homes in California
description: A Mediterranean-style house in San Francisco, a midcentury home in Los Angeles and a Southwestern retreat in Sonoma.
content: Lone Mountain, a neighborhood a few blocks from the University of San Francisco, is considered a hidden gem by many home buyers: The wide streets are quiet and tree-lined, and many of the houses (including this one) are within walking distance of at least one park. This home is across the street from Rossi Park, which has a public swimming pool and a baseball diamond, and a few blocks from a section of Golden Gate Park with grassy meadows and a Victorian-era greenhouse. Driving to Marin County via the Golden Gate Bridge takes about 20 minutes; Fisherman’s Wharf is 15 minutes away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: If War Flames in Ukraine, These 2 Little Enclaves May Be the Spark
description: Russian-backed separatists in the Luhansk and Donetsk regions once got just passing attention. They loom much larger now as many fear what may come next in Ukraine.
content: STANYTSIA LUHANSKA, Ukraine — People pass the bare-bones checkpoint dragging wheeled suitcases along the muddy pavement, crossing one of the starkest political divides in Europe today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: N.Y.C. Council Leader Caught Between Members and Mayor on Tackling Crime
description: Adrienne Adams, the new City Council speaker, is playing a leading role as New York officials confront a spike in violence that has gained national attention.
content: In a city accustomed to wave-making entrances from its elected leaders, Adrienne Adams, New York City’s new speaker of the City Council, has spent the first six weeks in a relatively splash-free zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Doom Watching ‘Euphoria’
description: It’s one of the most popular shows on television right now. But sometimes even the fans need to calm down after an episode.
content: Every Sunday around 9 p.m., Maddie Bone and her five roommates, all in their 20s and 30s, dim the lights in their Brooklyn apartment, fire up the projector and turn on HBO Max — with subtitles, just in case the J train rattles by. They also brew a pot of Sleepytime tea, not to help them drift off but to keep their nerves at bay while they watch the heart-racing fever dream that is “Euphoria.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Atul Loke
title: Risking Their Lives, for Little Pay, to Guard India’s Forests
description: Braving tigers and other dangers, frontline workers face difficult working conditions as they try to keep the peace between humans and wildlife.
content: WAYANAD, India — Armed only with a bamboo stick, Bijesh T.K. was part of a team looking for a tiger that had escaped from a wildlife sanctuary. But it was the tiger that saw him first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Horowitz
title: Finnegan, Dog Known for His Exemplary Nose, Dies at 14
description: In life, animals are rarely treated with the respect due these fellow travelers on earth; when they die, we have one last chance to do so.
content: Finnegan Horowitz Shea, a charismatic and sniffy mixed breed dog featured in several books on dog cognition and perception, died in New York City on Jan. 21. He was 14½ years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Troops in Poland Brace for Possible Ukrainian Evacuees
description: Tens of thousands of people, including Americans, could flee across the border if Russia launches a full invasion of Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — Many of the nearly 5,000 troops from the 82nd Airborne Division who arrived in Poland last week are working with Polish forces to set up processing centers for tens of thousands of people, including Americans, who are expected to flee neighboring Ukraine if Russia launches a full-scale invasion of the country, U.S. military officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Housing Operator Fights Students, Investors and Now a Wall St. Colossus
description: Investors say Nelson Partners owes them tens of millions, and student tenants complain about poorly run properties. Now a $54 billion investment firm is in the mix.
content: A student-housing operator that tenants and investors say has badly mismanaged high-end properties across the country has added a Wall Street colossus to the list of legal opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Barococo’ Review: Fop Till You Drop
description: Happenstance Theater traps five pretentious aristocrats in a comedy of bad manners that could use more luster and more bite.
content: Playing parlor games, dancing the minuet, making snide comments — aristocrats sure do know how to party. But there’s always a chance that by the end of the night someone will lose their head …
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Photos: Eastern Ukraine on Monday.
description: Soldiers and residents tried to prepare for a possible escalation of war in the eastern part of Ukraine.
content: Soldiers and residents tried to prepare for a possible escalation of war in the eastern part of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Russia is poised on Ukraine’s border after a weekend of shelling and evacuations in the east.
description: Russian military exercises on Ukraine’s border were extended indefinitely on Sunday, leaving the threat of an invasion hanging over a vastly outgunned Ukrainian military and a jittery civilian population after a weekend of shelling and evacuations that American and Ukrainian officials warned was an effort by Moscow to create a pretext for an invasion.
content: Russian military exercises on Ukraine’s border were extended indefinitely on Sunday, leaving the threat of an invasion hanging over a vastly outgunned Ukrainian military and a jittery civilian population after a weekend of shelling and evacuations that American and Ukrainian officials warned was an effort by Moscow to create a pretext for an invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: At a pro-Ukraine rally, priests pray for the dead and diplomats hope for peace.
description: WASHINGTON — Just above the Reflecting Pool, on the steps leading to the Lincoln Memorial, hundreds of people gathered on Sunday to remember the approximately 14,000 Ukrainian lives lost since 2014 in the fighting with Russian-backed separatists in the country’s east.
content: WASHINGTON — Just above the Reflecting Pool, on the steps leading to the Lincoln Memorial, hundreds of people gathered on Sunday to remember the approximately 14,000 Ukrainian lives lost since 2014 in the fighting with Russian-backed separatists in the country’s east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Somehow, Trump Is a Tough Act to Follow
description: “How do you solve a problem like the Donald?”
content: Gail Collins: Bret, what would you be doing now if you were Mitch McConnell?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Hiltner
title: Six Days Afloat in the Everglades
description: After a storm disrupted plans for a 99-mile paddling trek, a Times journalist’s time on the water took a more reflective turn. Come look and listen alongside him.
content: From a distance, the mouth of the creek was indistinguishable from the thick tangle of mangroves that concealed it — as if the narrow waterway were only willing to reveal itself to those who knew to look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Popkin and Leslie Brice
title: Can a Hidden World Be Saved From an Invasive Scourge?
description: The emerald ash border threatens ash trees that anchor a unique world on the Delmarva Peninsula.
content: On the Delmarva Peninsula, the low-lying expanse of coastal plain that bulges east from the Chesapeake Bay, some of the last remaining sizable green and wild spaces are wetland forests that shroud tidal rivers and creeks on their languid journeys toward the bay: the Nanticoke, the Marshyhope, the Choptank, the Tuckahoe, the Pocomoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: Japan Wants to Showcase Gold Mines’ History. Just Not All of It.
description: A bid for a UNESCO World Heritage designation is the latest flash point between Japan and South Korea over Japanese colonial abuses during World War II.
content: SADO ISLAND, Japan — About 40 miles off the northwestern coast of Japan, Akiyoshi Iwasaki is eager to share some history of the mountainous, lightning-bolt-shaped isle where he grew up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Dhawan
title: Ignoring a Text Message or Email Isn’t Always Rude. Sometimes It’s Necessary.
description: Ignoring a Slack, email or text message feels rude, but should it?
content: It was a Tuesday night. In my apartment, I was doing three things at once — packing for a short business trip, trying to get dinner on the table for my family and taking turns with my husband to calm a crying baby. Behind me, one work Slack alert after another dinged from my laptop. I ignored them all. During dinner, a text popped up on my phone. “Where are u????” asked my colleague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Hank the Tank, a 500-Pound Bear, Ransacks a California Community
description: Paintballs, bean bags, sirens and Tasers cannot keep the “exceptionally large bear” from seeking leftover pizza and other food. Officials say he has broken into at least 28 homes since July.
content: Since the summer, a black bear known as Hank the Tank has made a 500-pound nuisance of himself in South Lake Tahoe, Calif., breaking into more than two dozen homes to rummage for food and leaving a trail of damage behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Park Slope and Staten Island: An Unlikely Political Marriage
description: New congressional maps that merge conservative Staten Island with liberal Park Slope will aid Democratic efforts to win a Republican-held House seat in New York.
content: At The Original Goodfella’s, a well-known Staten Island pizzeria where photographs of Republican politicians are prominently displayed, the news sank in painfully: This borough, a rare conservative outpost of New York City, was being tossed into a congressional district with the liberal residents of Park Slope, Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Eskenazi
title: Emile Francis Built the Rangers His Way
description: Francis, who died Saturday at 95, installed a no-nonsense culture as the Rangers’ general manager and coach. His tenure included nine consecutive playoff appearances.
content: Emile Francis came to New York and found a hockey wasteland. By the time he had finished his stints as the general manager and coach of the Rangers, he had made them a significant player among the city’s many professional sports teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Says Police Didn’t Hack Civilians Without Court Approval
description: An official investigation refuted claims that the police had illegally hacked dozens of civilians using spyware from NSO Group, an Israeli company that has long attracted global scrutiny.
content: TEL AVIV — The Israeli justice ministry announced Monday that its weekslong investigation had found no evidence to suggest the Israeli police had systematically bypassed judicial oversight to hack the phones of civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Farewell, Readers, It’s Been a Remarkable Ride
description: Before I go, I want to highlight the breathtaking evolution in health advice that has occurred since I joined The Times in 1965.
content: The very first Personal Health column, published in The New York Times on Nov. 10, 1976, appeared under a headline that I, its author, took seriously and hoped readers would too: “Jogging Is Like a Drug: Watch Dosage, Beware the Problems.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: The Senate’s Most Vulnerable Democrats
description: With inflation and President Biden’s sinking poll ratings beleaguering the party, incumbents in four battleground states — Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and New Hampshire — face tough campaigns.
content: Two senators from states with little in common and at opposite poles of the country found each other this month: Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire and Mark Kelly of Arizona, who banded together to push a gasoline tax holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6, Episode 5 Recap: All in the Family
description: This week, the ties that bind are feeling extra tight for Chuck, Prince and Scooter.
content: It shouldn’t come as a surprise that “Billions,” the most “Godfather”-quoting show on television — this episode alone included references to the “Part II” antagonist Don Fanucci and Vito Corleone’s regret that his son Michael would never become governor or senator — put family at the heart of its story lines. This week, family was the story line for three of the show’s most important characters. And surprisingly, no one involved got shot to death in a rowboat, metaphorically speaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Bernie Madoff’s Sister and Her Husband Are Found Dead in Florida
description: The authorities said it appeared to be a murder-suicide.
content: Bernie Madoff’s sister, Sondra Wiener, and her husband were found dead on Thursday in their home in Boynton Beach, Fla., in what the authorities said was an apparent murder-suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: On the ground: A column of Russian vehicles, and soldiers without insignia.
description: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — Multiple military vehicles and soldiers with no insignia were seen parked on highways on Monday, in the vicinity of Rostov-on-Don, a major Russian city about 60 miles from the border with Ukraine.
content: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — Multiple military vehicles and soldiers with no insignia were seen parked on highways on Monday, in the vicinity of Rostov-on-Don, a major Russian city about 60 miles from the border with Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: A Key to Returning to Normal Is Paid Sick Leave, Democrats Say
description: There were a record number of people home sick with Covid in January. Democrats are trying to revive paid pandemic sick leave.
content: The Omicron wave hammered the American work force, sending more people home sick than at any other point in the pandemic. Yet unlike in 2020, there is no federally required paid sick leave for workers — and none at all for the one-fifth of workers who don’t receive it from their employers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: A Successful Pandemic Olympics?
description: Evaluating the zero Covid Games.
content: When the Winter Olympics in Beijing began earlier this month, the stakes were high: Tens of thousands of people were entering China as the more contagious Omicron variant was spreading rapidly worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Jamal Edwards, Force in British Rap, Dies at 31
description: Edwards set up SB.TV, one of the first YouTube channels dedicated to British rap music, and was also key to Ed Sheeran’s early success.
content: LONDON — Jamal Edwards, the founder of a music YouTube channel that gave an early platform to British rap stars including Stormzy, Skepta and Dave, as well as pop stars like Ed Sheeran, died on Sunday. He was 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
title: U.S. still sees an invasion as imminent, dimming hopes for a Biden-Putin summit.
description: WASHINGTON — Top American officials said on Monday that a Russian invasion of Ukraine remained imminent amid continued troop movements, propaganda and bellicose language from Moscow, suggesting that prospects are dim for a summit between President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin in the days ahead.
content: WASHINGTON — Top American officials said on Monday that a Russian invasion of Ukraine remained imminent amid continued troop movements, propaganda and bellicose language from Moscow, suggesting that prospects are dim for a summit between President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin in the days ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Black Farmers Fear Foreclosure as Debt Relief Remains Frozen
description: Lawsuits from white farmers have blocked $4 billion of pandemic aid that was allocated to Black farmers in the American Rescue Plan.
content: WASHINGTON — For Brandon Smith, a fourth-generation cattle rancher from Texas, the $1.9 trillion stimulus package that President Biden signed into law nearly a year ago was long-awaited relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Highlights from Putin’s address on breakaway regions in Ukraine.
description: President Vladimir V. Putin said he would recognize the independence of two Russia-backed territories in eastern Ukraine. Here are highlights from his 40-minute speech.
content: It was a seminal, hourlong speech that threatened to clear the way for war. On Monday night President Vladimir V. Putin said he would recognize the independence of two Russia-backed territories in eastern Ukraine, setting the stage for the possibility of Russian military action against Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski
title: Putin says Russia will decide on Monday whether to recognize breakaway regions.
description: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin kept an anxious world guessing about whether he plans to invade Ukraine, announcing on Monday that he would decide by the end of the day whether to recognize the independence of two breakaway regions of Ukraine.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin kept an anxious world guessing about whether he plans to invade Ukraine, announcing on Monday that he would decide by the end of the day whether to recognize the independence of two breakaway regions of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Julian E. Barnes and Anton Troianovski
title: U.S. says Russia has a list of Ukrainians to kill or detain after an invasion.
description: A U.S. ambassador cited “credible information” that Russian forces have compiled a list of Ukrainians to be targeted after an invasion.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States government has sent a letter to the United Nations human rights chief in Geneva saying it has “credible information” that Russian forces have compiled a list of Ukrainian citizens to be killed or sent to detention camps in the aftermath of a Russian invasion and occupation of the country, according to a copy of the letter obtained Sunday by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Roger Cohen
title: Air France is the latest airline to limit flights to Ukraine.
description: Lufthansa and Scandinavian Airlines also canceled flights to Kyiv as fears grow of a Russian invasion.
content: As tensions mount in Ukraine, more airlines are limiting or suspending flights into the country despite the government’s effort to keep the airspace open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Ukraine Is Different
description: A Russian invasion of Ukraine would be unlike most wars in 80 years.
content: There have been dozens of wars in the almost 80 years since World War II ended. But if Russia invades Ukraine in the coming days, it will be different from almost all of them. It will be another sign that the world may be entering an alarming new era in which authoritarianism is on the rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Arkush
title: Harold Varner and the 92-Foot Putt That Could Get Him a Masters Invitation
description: The American golfer missed the cut last week at the Genesis Invitational, but he was still riding high from a wild win in the Saudi International.
content: LOS ANGELES — Harold Varner III did not make the cut in the Genesis Invitational at Riviera Country Club. He did not come close. He started bogey, double bogey, bogey on his first three holes on Thursday on the way to a six-over-par 77. Despite rebounding with a 69 on Friday, he missed the cut by four strokes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Watergate: A New History,’ by Garrett M. Graff: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Watergate: A New History,” by Garrett M. Graff
content: As the thirty-seventh occupant of his office, Richard Nixon had settled into the White House under a new reality: Washington, D.C., had changed dramatically since World War II, as what had once been a relatively sleepy southern town conducting part-time business had morphed into the all-consuming locus of federal power, directing the world’s largest economy and driving foreign affairs the world over. With that shift—and the massive and ever-swelling bureaucracy that came with it—the presidency had changed too; what for much of America’s first two centuries had been the office tasked with executing policy and spending money decided and set by Congress had seen that power dynamic reverse and instead now piloted the national agenda itself. It was a job now far too big for one man, even as the White House absorbed, stole, and agglomerated still more power and personnel. To Nixon, figuring out how to staff the oversized presidency—whom to trust, how to inspire them and manage them—consumed far too much energy. “It would be god damn easy to run this office if you didn’t have to deal with people,” he lamented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1897: Queen Victoria’s Diamond Jubilee Proposals
description: The plans to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the British monarch’s accession included a service at St. Paul’s Cathedral.
content: [By the Herald’s Special Wire] LONDON, Feb, 21. — It is now definitely announced that the service at St. Paul’s Cathedral to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee of her Majesty will be held on Tuesday, June 22. The City Press states that owing to the fact that the Queen does not desire to undergo the fatigue of leaving her carriage and ascending the steps of the cathedral, the service will be held on the western steps, The Royal carriage being drawn up in the open space before the West front. The Westminster Gazette says such a service would be unique in the annals of the City Cathedral. “Meanwhile,” writes a representative of that paper who has been making inquiries, “it would be injudicious to assume the accuracy of the foregoing statement, seeing that nothing has, as yet, been decided on the subject whatever, and so far as the Cathedral authorities are concerned, at all events, it is very doubtful whether they would lend their approval to any such scheme as that foreshadowed, the objections to which, it is urged, are many and serious. We understand that a meeting of the committee which has the matter in hand, over which Dean Gregory presides, and at which the Prince of Wales will be present, will be held this afternoon for further consideration of the matter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: 8 Subway Attacks Over Weekend Show Challenge Adams Faces on Crime
description: The mayor and governor released a safety plan for the subways that focused on homelessness. But a homeless person was believed to be responsible in only one of the weekend attacks.
content: The weekend after Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul announced a plan to address safety concerns on New York City’s subways that focused on stopping homeless people from sheltering in the system, at least eight violent incidents took place in stations and on trains, only one of which involved an attacker who appeared to be homeless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Justin Bieber tests positive for the coronavirus, leading to the postponement of shows.
description: Two performances, so far, are being rescheduled, his tour said, after an outbreak “within the team.”
content: The singer Justin Bieber has tested positive for the coronavirus, one day after he began his world tour in San Diego on Friday, a representative for Mr. Bieber confirmed on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Goodbye, Hades. Hello, Scotland. Amber Gray Parts With Persephone.
description: The actress, who has played Persephone in “Hadestown” in three countries and four productions, is leaving to join a new “Macbeth” on Broadway.
content: Amber Gray spent eight years as a Greek goddess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: U.S. Museums See Rise in Unions Even as Labor Movement Slumps
description: Workers at nearly two dozen American art museums have created collective bargaining units in recent years to push for better pay and working conditions.
content: The carpenters and the security guards at the Philadelphia Museum of Art had long been members of a union when in 2020, workers from departments across the museum — curators, conservators, educators and librarians — voted to create one of the largest museum unions in the country with nearly 250 members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Are You Planning a Pandemic Wedding? We’re Looking for Advice.
description: We’re looking for tips on hosting a large event during the pandemic.
content: As we look toward a future of living with the virus, some of us are thinking about planning larger events that we’ve postponed for two years, like weddings, family reunions or conventions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Liz Alderman
title: How Europeans Are Responding to Exorbitant Gas and Power Bills
description: High energy prices in Europe are upending people’s lives. While some are installing solar panels, others are stoking their wood-burning stoves.
content: A German retiree facing sky-high energy bills is turning to a wood-burning stove. The owner of a dry cleaning business in Spain adjusted her employees’ work shifts to cut electric bills and installed solar panels. A mayor in France said he ordered a hiring freeze because rising electrical bills threaten a financial “catastrophe.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 21, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 21, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin’s Security Council meets as the Kremlin warns that ‘tensions are rising.’
description: The United States says Russia stands poised to attack Ukraine amid a frantic diplomatic push.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was holding an unscheduled meeting of his Security Council on Monday, as the Kremlin said that “tensions are rising” and the U.S. continued warnings that his nation stands poised to attack Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: If war ignites in Ukraine, two little enclaves could be the spark.
description: With Ukraine surrounded by Russian forces, Western governments warn that Moscow may use the two Russian-backed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk as the stage for a “false flag” attack on ethnic Russian civilians — and then cite it as justification when they storm across the border.
content: With Ukraine surrounded by Russian forces, Western governments warn that Moscow may use the two Russian-backed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk as the stage for a “false flag” attack on ethnic Russian civilians — and then cite it as justification when they storm across the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: For Ukraine’s Jews, the Threat of War Stirs Memories of Past Horrors
description: In Odessa, Jewish leaders are preparing for the worst: hiring security guards, scoping out bomb shelters and making plans to evacuate if Russia invades the country.
content: ODESSA, Ukraine—Rabbi Avraham Wolff is preparing for war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Times Wins 2 Polk Awards for Investigative Reporting
description: The Times was honored for coverage that revealed a plot behind the murder of the Haitian president and for investigations on the toll of America’s air war in the Middle East.
content: The New York Times won two George Polk Awards for investigative reporting that uncovered corruption and drug trafficking behind the assassination of the Haitian president and revealed extensive details about U.S. airstrikes in the Middle East that killed civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Jack Ewing
title: What’s at Stake for the Global Economy as Conflict Looms in Ukraine
description: Countries that depend on the region’s rich supply of energy, wheat, nickel and other staples could feel the pain of price spikes.
content: After getting battered by the pandemic, supply chain chokeholds and leaps in prices, the global economy is poised to be sent on yet another unpredictable course by an armed clash on Europe’s border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Bomb Threats Are Roiling Historically Black Colleges and Universities
description: White supremacists have been targeting Black schools and churches across America since their foundings.
content: NASHVILLE — Last week, officials at Fisk University ordered a lockdown while investigators responded to a bomb threat on campus. When I heard the news, my first reaction was a gut-wrenching sense of inevitability, and not just because more than 20 historically Black colleges and universities have received bomb threats in the last three weeks. White supremacists in the South — and far beyond the South — have been targeting Black schools and churches since these institutions were first founded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Medina Spirit Stripped of 2021 Kentucky Derby Win
description: The horse’s trainer, Bob Baffert, was suspended and fined after his horse failed a post-race drug test last year.
content: Medina Spirit is no longer the winner of the 2021 Kentucky Derby. The colt, who died unexpectedly in December, was officially disqualified by Kentucky racing officials on Monday for failing a drug test after winning the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Who Do Americans Think Should Pay for College?
description: As student loan debt continues to pile up, the question has never been more urgent.
content: Ten years ago, the idea that policies like student loan debt forgiveness or free two-year college would soon be debated in mainstream national politics would have sounded ridiculous. I was writing my first book on higher education during that time, and as I traveled across the country and occasionally abroad to talk about college in America, I got two questions every time: “Why don’t people worried about student loans just get a job to pay their tuition?” and “Why shouldn’t private for-profit companies make money on college when Harvard does the same thing?” These questions were driven by folk economics: People had filled a lot of gaps in their understanding about the mechanics of debt and tuition with a simplified view of how college works. Neither of these questions suggested the sea change that was coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Putin Recognizes Separatists in Ukraine
description: Western officials warn that Russia is paving a path toward war.
content: In a fiery speech filled with historical grievances, President Vladimir Putin said on Monday that Russia would recognize the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk, territories in Ukraine controlled by Moscow-backed separatists. Western leaders fear the move could lead to one of the biggest conflicts in Europe since World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Moves to Lift Coronavirus Restrictions in England
description: The British prime minister is shifting toward a strategy of living with Covid-19. Critics argue that the move is too soon, even as case numbers fall.
content: LONDON — After almost two years of restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain said on Monday that it was time to live with the coronavirus, announcing an end to England’s remaining legal curbs and most free testing, and making his country an outlier in its handling of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Fortress Australia’ Has a New Message: Come Back
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 21, 2022.
content: “People are really ready to start thinking about these bucket-list trips again. I think for a lot of Americans, Australia is a bucket-list type trip.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: In an Uneven Fight With China, a Tiny Country’s Brand Becomes Toxic
description: After Lithuania dared to seek closer ties with Taiwan, China cut off trade — even blocking imports of products from other countries with Lithuanian parts.
content: VILNIUS, Lithuania — A family-owned semiconductor company in Lithuania sold nothing to China, so it did not worry much last year when Beijing, furious at the Baltic nation for cozying up to Taiwan, began blocking imports of milk products, peat and anything else it could find with a “Made in Lithuania” label.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Swift and Ellen Barry
title: In an Arctic Outpost, Friday Nights Are for Curling
description: In a town with one stoplight, 120 miles above the Arctic Circle, curling provides women with a reason to leave their houses. And that is no small thing.
content: INUVIK, Northwest Territories — Alison Lennie steps out of her house into 29 degrees below zero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Arab Rulers and Spy Chiefs Stashed Millions in Swiss Bank
description: A leak of account data from Credit Suisse revealed the holdings of powerful figures across the Middle East, raising new questions about self-dealing.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The king and queen of Jordan had secret Swiss bank accounts worth hundreds of millions of dollars, according to a major data leak from one of Switzerland’s largest banks. So did the sons of Hosni Mubarak, the ousted president of Egypt, and business tycoons who thrived during his 30-year rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Boris Johnson warns that Russia is planning the biggest war in Europe since 1945.
description: Russia is planning “the biggest war in Europe since 1945,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain told the BBC on Sunday, warning that a conflict would be a “catastrophe” for Russia.
content: Russia is planning “the biggest war in Europe since 1945,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain told the BBC on Sunday, warning that a conflict would be a “catastrophe” for Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Got a Covid Booster? You Probably Won’t Need Another for a Long Time
description: A flurry of new studies suggest that several parts of the immune system can mount a sustained, potent response to any coronavirus variant.
content: As people across the world grapple with the prospect of living with the coronavirus for the foreseeable future, one question looms large: How soon before they need yet another shot?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Ducker
title: Sasami Wanted to Appropriate White, Male Music. She Landed on Metal.
description: The 31-year-old Los Angeles musician’s first album was filled with electro-inflected indie rock. Its follow-up, “Squeeze,” has harder music filtered through her unique lens.
content: LOS ANGELES — For most of 2020, Sasami didn’t feel like it was an appropriate time for her to make music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Frederick Douglass: In Five Speeches’ and Awards Shows
description: A new documentary about Frederick Douglass debuts on HBO. And both the Screen Actors Guild Awards and the N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards air this weekend.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 21-27. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: When People Take Pandemic Precautions, Gorillas Breathe Easier
description: A preliminary report suggests that mask wearing and social distancing may curb the spread of disease from humans to great apes.
content: The mountain gorillas that live in Rwanda’s Volcanoes National Park have frequent encounters with humans. On any given day, the animals might come across smartphone-toting tourists, fecal-sample-swiping biologists or antibiotic-administering veterinarians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: At Rothko Chapel, a Composer Is Haunted by a Hero
description: Tyshawn Sorey’s “Monochromatic Light (Afterlife),” for the 50th anniversary of the Houston space, closely echoes Morton Feldman’s “Rothko Chapel.”
content: HOUSTON — The canvases that surround you at the Rothko Chapel here can at first seem merely dark. Entering the space after nightfall on Saturday, the interior dimly lit, I struggled to see much of anything in them at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: U.S. House Candidate Apologizes for Behavior at Sleepover
description: Parents said Abby Broyles of Oklahoma drank and swore at children at a friend’s home. She said she had mixed wine with medication and had no memory of the night.
content: A Democratic candidate for Congress in Oklahoma apologized in a television interview on Friday after parents complained that she drank and verbally abused children attending a sleepover at a friend’s home this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: menagerie
description: This word has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word menagerie has appeared in 47 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 10 in “As Its Population Soars to 40, Rum Isle Glimpses a Future in the Mist” by Stephen Castle:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Emma Bubola
title: Ukrainians abroad rally in support of their friends and families at home.
description: As Russia appeared to be preparing for a military incursion into Ukraine, diaspora groups in cities worldwide took to the streets to express solidarity with friends and family back home — waving Ukrainian flags, singing nationalist songs and holding placards denouncing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
content: As Russia appeared to be preparing for a military incursion into Ukraine, diaspora groups in cities worldwide took to the streets to express solidarity with friends and family back home — waving Ukrainian flags, singing nationalist songs and holding placards denouncing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D'Angelo Lovell Williams and Ian Bradley
title: This Spring, Men’s Fashion Channels a Sensual New Energy
description: Feminine touches, from dramatic volumes to heady floral prints, infuse classic pieces with fresh appeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Putin’s plan to invade Ukraine.
content: Acting on the advice of American intelligence agencies, President Biden said on Friday he was convinced that Vladimir Putin would attack Ukraine “in the coming week, in the coming days.” But how the Russian leader will do it — all at once, as senior U.S. military and intelligence officials expect, or in a series of smaller attacks — remains unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Paul Willen, Architect of Manhattan’s Waterfront, Dies at 93
description: His plan for a former rail yard became the template for a neighborhood created by a coalition of civic groups and a brash developer named Donald Trump.
content: Paul Willen, an architect and civic advocate who helped turn Trump City, a plan for a massive development on Manhattan’s West Side, into a tamer, gentler and more livable neighborhood called Riverside South, died on Feb. 2 in Berlin, Vt. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ian Austen
title: After Trucker Protest, Canada Grapples With a Question: Was It a Blip, or Something Bigger?
description: The demonstrators were passionate, organized and supported financially, but such spontaneous movements often have a tough time converting their energy into real change.
content: OTTAWA — A cavalcade of big rigs rumbled into the Canadian capital, blocked major streets, drew thousands of supporters, enraged residents and captured the attention of a shocked nation for three weeks. Now they’re gone, leaving Canadians to grapple with some high-stakes questions about their country’s political future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Crypto Scammers’ New Target: Dating Apps
description: “Everything was a lie,” said one woman lured into a recent scam.
content: The man from the dating app Hinge checked all of Tho Vu’s boxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Why it matters that Russia just recognized Donetsk and Luhansk.
description: The act of recognition is fraught with meaning because the borders claimed by the Russia-backed leaders of the two breakaway regions extend into space controlled by the Ukrainian army.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has recognized the independence of two separatist regions in Ukraine, a move many fear may be the spark for a Russian military intervention against Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: I.R.S. Will Allow Taxpayers to Forgo Facial Recognition Amid Blowback
description: The agency, dealing with controversy over its decision to use facial recognition software, said it would allow taxpayers to authenticate their accounts with a live, virtual interview.
content: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service said on Monday that it would allow taxpayers to opt out of using facial recognition technology to gain access to their online accounts and would shift to an entirely different identity verification system next year as the agency tries to alleviate backlash over its use of biometric data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 12 Soothing Braises to Help You Get Through the Rest of Winter
description: A few hours on the stove or in the oven does wonders, turning hearty short ribs and dense root vegetables soft and silky.
content: Braising is transformative. For generations, cooks across cultures have turned to the technique to create luscious comfort food from the toughest of meats, greens and beans. The beauty is not only in what it can create, but also in what it affords you: In many of the recipes below, the bulk of the cook time is hands-off. Simply sear, simmer and step away from the kitchen until the irresistible aromas call you back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Uproar Over ‘Crack Pipes’ Puts Biden Drug Strategy at Risk
description: President Biden has made “harm reduction” a central pillar of his plan to fight a record number of drug-related deaths, but a conservative backlash is threatening the effort.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden came into office vowing to make “harm reduction” — a public health approach geared toward helping drug users stay safe rather than abstain — a central pillar of his drug policy agenda, at a time when illicit fentanyl has driven a surge in overdose deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry and Alex Traub
title: Paul Farmer, Pioneer of Global Health, Dies at 62
description: As a medical student, Dr. Farmer decided to build a clinic in Haiti. It grew into a vast network serving some of the world’s poorest communities.
content: Paul Farmer, a physician, anthropologist and humanitarian who gained global acclaim for his work delivering high-quality health care to some of the world’s poorest people, died on Monday on the grounds of a hospital and university he had helped establish in Butaro, Rwanda. He was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: France says Biden and Putin agree to meet in ‘principle,’ but obstacles remain.
description: PARIS — President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have “accepted the principle” of a summit meeting to be held some time after Thursday, the French presidency said in a statement on Monday.
content: PARIS — President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have “accepted the principle” of a summit meeting to be held some time after Thursday, the French presidency said in a statement on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Photographers’ Favorite Olympic Images
description: Times photographers sought to capture every aspect of the Olympic Games in Beijing. These pictures were special to them.
content: Over the last several weeks, a team of New York Times photographers sought to capture every aspect of the Olympic Games in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Small Cabinets
description: Because they’re incredibly useful if you’re furnishing a small space.
content: When you’re furnishing a small space, finding cabinets that are just the right size can be a challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Margaret Atwood’s Essays and Speeches, Some Hazards of the Trade
description: “Burning Questions” collects sundry pieces the author has written (and sometimes spoken) since 2004.
content: Mamas, don’t let your babies grow up to collect their PEN International speeches between hard covers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Yale’s Happiness Professor Says Anxiety Is Destroying Her Students
description: The cognitive scientist Laurie Santos says “we’re fighting cultural forces that are telling us, ‘You’re not happy enough.’”
content: The cognitive scientist Laurie Santos says “we’re fighting cultural forces that are telling us, ‘You’re not happy enough.’”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Maps: Tracking the Conflict Between Ukraine and Russia
description: Military and strategic maps in the ongoing Ukraine-Russia crisis.
content: Military and strategic maps in the ongoing Ukraine-Russia crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $4 Million in California
description: A Mediterranean-style house in San Francisco, a midcentury home in Los Angeles and a Southwestern retreat in Sonoma.
content: A Mediterranean-style house in San Francisco, a midcentury home in Los Angeles and a Southwestern retreat in Sonoma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Consider country captain for dinner and pineapple-ginger coffee cake for dessert.
content: Good morning. Happy Presidents’ Day. Ligaya Mishan had a lovely essay on the origins of country captain in The Times last week, tracing the fragrant, curried chicken dish from its home in the Lowcountry of the American South to its origins in Britain and India, “a legacy of colonials with palates newly awakened to the possibilities of spice.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The I.C.U. Patient, and the Family
description: Exploring the dilemmas involving patients, their families and health care providers in end-of-life care. Also: Quotation marks; calling and driving.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
